conclusion: Objects C and D (yellow and purple blocks) are fixed on the left side of the table, and objects E and F (green and pink blocks) are fixed on the right side of the table. Objects A (plaid cloth) and B (blue cloth) are initially held in the air above those blocks.
Objects C and D are yellow and purple blocks, while objects E and F are green and pink blocks. Objects A and B are plaid and blue cloths, respectively.
Gravity pulls cloth A downward until it strikes the tops and vertical faces of blocks C and D.
Gravity pulls cloth B downward until it strikes the tops and vertical faces of blocks E and F.
Cloth A lands partly on the yellow and purple blocks (C and D), draping over their edges.
Cloth B lands partly on the green and pink blocks (E and F), draping over their edges.
Because the blocks stand higher than the tabletop, each cloth continues sliding down the block faces.
The corners of each cloth that are not pinned sag toward the tabletop, producing a tent-like shape.
Cloth A forms a draped surface covering most of blocks C and D, touching the table around them.
Cloth B forms a similar drape over blocks E and F.
No further motion occurs once the cloth pieces have fully conformed to the blocks and the tabletop.

Both pieces of cloth (objects A and B) drop under gravity, collide with their respective block pairs (C–D and E–F), slide down the block faces, and finally come to rest draped over the blocks and lying on the tabletop around them.
